elements.content: Three novel interesting coordination polymers, [Cd3(SIP)2(bbi)5·3H2O] n (1), [Co3(SIP)2(bix)4(2H2O)·2H2O] n (2), and [Cd(2,5-pydc)2(bix)1.5·H2O] n (3) (SIP = 5-sulfoisophthalic acid monosodium salt; bbi = 1,1‘-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole); bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene; 2,5-pydc = pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid), have been isolated under hydrothermal conditions and structurally characterized. Polymer 1 has a 3D complicated framework comprised of an infinite 1D ladder-like chain and 2D layer structure. Polymer 2 features a 3D hydrated framework with uncoordinated water molecules trapped in the pores. Polymer 3 is a 2D infinite layer framework, which is further interconnected by hydrogen-bond interactions to lead to a 3D supramolecular architecture. Compounds 1 and 3 exhibit medium-strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature and could be significant in the field of photoactive materials.
elements.clean_text: Three novel interesting coordination polymers, [Cd3(SIP)2(bbi)5⋅3H2O] n  (1), [Co3(SIP)2(bix)4(2H2O)⋅2H2O] n  (2), and [Cd(2,5-pydc)2(bix)1.5⋅H2O] n  (3) (SIP = 5-sulfoisophthalic acid monosodium salt; bbi = 1,1‘-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole); bix = 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene; 2,5-pydc = pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid), have been isolated under hydrothermal conditions and structurally characterized. Polymer 1 has a 3D complicated framework comprised of an infinite 1D ladder-like chain and 2D layer structure. Polymer 2 features a 3D hydrated framework with uncoordinated water molecules trapped in the pores. Polymer 3 is a 2D infinite layer framework, which is further interconnected by hydrogen-bond interactions to lead to a 3D supramolecular architecture. Compounds 1 and 3 exhibit medium-strong fluorescent emissions in the solid state at room temperature and could be significant in the field of photoactive materials.

elements.content: Three novel interesting cadmium(II) or cobalt(II) metal coordination polymers with different architectures were assembled from aromatic polycarboxylate acid and flexible imidazole-based synthons under mild hydrothermal conditions. Their crystal structures, TG measurements, and photoluminescence properties were investigated.
elements.clean_text: Three novel interesting cadmium(II) or cobalt(II) metal coordination polymers with different architectures were assembled from aromatic polycarboxylate acid and flexible imidazole-based synthons under mild hydrothermal conditions. Their crystal structures, TG measurements, and photoluminescence properties were investigated.

elements.content: Crystal engineering based on metal−organic frameworks (MOFs) has recently attracted considerable interest, owing to their versatile framework topologies as well as their potential applications as functional materials in molecular magnetism, catalysis, gas sorption, fluorescent sensing, and optoelectronic devices.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Crystal engineering based on metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has recently attracted considerable interest, owing to their versatile framework topologies as well as their potential applications as functional materials in molecular magnetism, catalysis, gas sorption, fluorescent sensing, and optoelectronic devices.

elements.content: Over the past few years, of the many MOF compounds investigated, a rich variety of high-dimensional structures have been constructed by the use of multidentate O-donor organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands. Although aromatic multicarboxylate ligands containing sulfonate moieties or N-donors, for example, 5-sulfoisophthalic acid monosodium salt (SIP) and pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (2,5-pydc) (Chart ), have been less explored in the synthesis of coordination polymers, recent studies have shed some light on their rich solid-state coordination modes. In order to further understand the coordination chemistry of SIP and 2,5-pydc and to prepare novel materials with beautiful architecture and good physical properties, we start to elaborate new high-dimensional coordination polymers constructed from the two polycarboxylate ligands. With the introduction of an auxiliary ligand, such as highly flexible imidazole-based 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bix) or 1,1‘-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole) (bbi) (Chart ), into the {M−polycarboxylate} (M = Cd2+ or Co2+), three new MOFs have been obtained. In the present paper, we report three interesting coordination polymeric complexes, [Cd3(SIP)2(bbi)5·3H2O] n (1), [Co3(SIP)2(bix)4(2H2O)·2H2O] n (2), and [Cd(2,5-pydc)2(bix)1.5·H2O] n (3).
elements.clean_text: Over the past few years, of the many MOF compounds investigated, a rich variety of high-dimensional structures have been constructed by the use of multidentate O-donor organic aromatic polycarboxylate ligands. Although aromatic multicarboxylate ligands containing sulfonate moieties or N-donors, for example, 5-sulfoisophthalic acid monosodium salt (SIP) and pyridine-2,5-dicarboxylic acid (2,5-pydc) (Chart ), have been less explored in the synthesis of coordination polymers, recent studies have shed some light on their rich solid-state coordination modes. In order to further understand the coordination chemistry of SIP and 2,5-pydc and to prepare novel materials with beautiful architecture and good physical properties, we start to elaborate new high-dimensional coordination polymers constructed from the two polycarboxylate ligands. With the introduction of an auxiliary ligand, such as highly flexible imidazole-based 1,4-bis(imidazol-1-ylmethyl)-benzene (bix) or 1,1‘-(1,4-butanediyl)bis(imidazole) (bbi) (Chart ), into the {M-polycarboxylate} (M = Cd2+ or Co2+), three new MOFs have been obtained. In the present paper, we report three interesting coordination polymeric complexes, [Cd3(SIP)2(bbi)5⋅3H2O] n  (1), [Co3(SIP)2(bix)4(2H2O)⋅2H2O] n  (2), and [Cd(2,5-pydc)2(bix)1.5⋅H2O] n  (3).

</fig>

Materials and Physical Measurement. The reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Ligands bix and bbi were synthesized as reported previously. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on KBr discs on a Bruker Vector 22 spectrophotometer in the 4000−400 cm-1 region. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min between ambient temperature and 800 °C. Luminescence spectra for the solid samples were recorded with a Hitachi 850 fluorescence spectrophotometer.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

 Materials and Physical Measurement. The reagents and solvents employed were commercially available and used as received without further purification. Ligands bix and bbi were synthesized as reported previously. The C, H, and N microanalyses were carried out with a Perkin-Elmer 240 elemental analyzer. The IR spectra were recorded on KBr discs on a Bruker Vector 22 spectrophotometer in the 4000-400 cm-1 region. Thermogravimetric analyses were performed on a simultaneous SDT 2960 thermal analyzer under flowing N2 with a heating rate of 10 °C/min between ambient temperature and 800 °C. Luminescence spectra for the solid samples were recorded with a Hitachi 850 fluorescence spectrophotometer.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cd 3 (SIP) 2 (bbi) 5 ·3H 2 O] n (1). A mixture of CdCl2·2H2O (0.0568 g, 0.25 mmol), SIP (0.0672 g, 0.25 mmol), bbi (0.0241 g, 0.125 mmol), NaOH (0.0304 g, 0.75 mmol), and H2O (3.0 mL) was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 cm3), and then the vessel was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals of 1 were obtained (yield 22% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C66H82Cd3N20O17S2:  C 43.35, H 4.52, N 15.32%. Found:  C 43.28, H 4.55, N 15.30%. IR (cm-1, KBr):  3429 s, 3116s, 1682 m, 1611 s, 1562 s, 1519 s, 1467 m, 1435 m, 1354 s, 1293 m, 1232 s, 1220 s, 1182 s, 1102 s, 1089 s, 1043 s, 997 m, 932 s, 867 m, 831 m, 791 m, 777 s, 741 m, 723 s, 682 m, 663 s, 623 s, 581 m, 512 w, 445 m, 410 w.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Co 3 (SIP) 2 (bix) 4 (2H 2 O)·2H 2 O] n (2). A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0730 g, 0.25 mmol), SIP (0.0665 g, 0.25 mmol), bix (0.0612 g, 0.25 mmol), NaOH (0.0204 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (3.0 mL) was heated in an analogous procedure to that for 1. After the reactant mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, purple crystals of 2 were obtained (yield 39% based on Co). Anal. Calcd for C72H70Co3N16O18S2:  C 51.22, H 4.18, N 13.27%. Found:  C 51.25, H 4.25, N 13.32%. IR (cm-1, KBr):  3382 m, 3140w, 1644 m, 1618 s, 1570 m, 1520 m, 1448 w, 1432 m, 1389 m, 1339 s, 1284 w, 1237 m, 1215 s, 1200 s, 1190 s, 1095 s, 1039 s, 1025 w, 997 w, 953 w, 940 w, 919w, 858 m, 834 m, 776 m, 755 m, 720 s, 661 s, 633 s, 585 m, 554 m, 519 w, 476 w.

elements.content: Synthesis of [Cd(2,5-pydc) 2 (bix) 1.5 ·H 2 O] n (3). A mixture of CdCl2·2H2O (0.0570 g, 0.25 mmol), 2,5-pydc (0.0422 g, 0.25 mmol), bix (0.0615 g, 0.25 mmol), NaOH (0.0212 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (3.0 mL) was heated at 140 °C for 3 days in an analogous to procedure to that for 1. After the reacant mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals of 3 were obtained (yield 55% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C28H26CdN7O5:  C 51.50, H 4.01, N 15.02%. Found:  C 51.53, H 4.06, N 15.04%. IR (cm-1, KBr):  3419 s, 3112 m, 1626 s, 1520 w, 1479 w, 1446 w, 1393 s, 1358 s, 1304 w, 1285 m, 1272 w, 1235 m, 1175 w, 1147 w, 1109 m, 1085 m, 1036 m, 934 m, 892 w, 831 s, 765 s, 742 w, 719 w, 691 m, 657 m, 622 w, 536 m, 519 m, 412 w.

After the reacant mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals of 3 were obtained (yield 55% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C28H26CdN7O5: C 51.50, H 4.01, N 15.02%. Found: C 51.53, H 4.06, N 15.04%. IR (cm-1, KBr): 3419 s, 3112 m, 1626 s, 1520 w, 1479 w, 1446 w, 1393 s, 1358 s, 1304 w, 1285 m, 1272 w, 1235 m, 1175 w, 1147 w, 1109 m, 1085 m, 1036 m, 934 m, 892 w, 831 s, 765 s, 742 w, 719 w, 691 m, 657 m, 622 w, 536 m, 519 m, 412 w.

elements.content: Single-Crystal Structure Determination. Suitable single crystals of 1−3 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. X-ray intensity data were measured at 293 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.710 73 Å). Data reductions and absorption corrections were performed with the SAINT and SADABS software packages, respectively. All structures were solved by a combination of direct methods and difference Fourier syntheses and refined against F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique. Anisotropic displacement parameters were refined for all non-hydrogen atoms except for the disordered atoms. Hydrogen atoms were added theoretically and were riding on their parent atoms. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for all compounds are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . More details on the crystallographic studies, as well as atom displacement parameters, are presented in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text: Single-Crystal  Structure Determination. Suitable single crystals of 1-3 were selected and mounted in air onto thin glass fibers. X-ray intensity data were measured at 293 K on a Bruker SMART APEX CCD-based diffractometer with graphite-monochromatic Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). Data reductions and absorption corrections were performed with the SAINT and SADABS software packages, respectively. All structures were solved by a combination of direct methods and difference Fourier syntheses and refined against F 2 by the full-matrix least-squares technique. Anisotropic displacement parameters were refined for all non-hydrogen atoms except for the disordered atoms. Hydrogen atoms were added theoretically and were riding on their parent atoms. The crystal parameters, data collection, and refinement results for all compounds are summarized in Table . Selected bond lengths and angles are listed in Table . More details on the crystallographic studies, as well as atom displacement parameters, are presented in the Supporting Information.

Syntheses. The mixture of metal salts and aromatic polycarboxylate with flexible imidazole-based spacers usually results in precipitation in traditional aqueous reactions, which makes it difficult to grow crystals of complexes. Therefore, complexes 1−3 were synthesized under hydrothermal methods. In addition, NaOH was introduced to deprotonate for aromatic polycarboxylate. Ligands SIP and 2,5-pydc can assume versatile coordination modes and are suitable H-bonding acceptors; meanwhile, both the flexible bix and bbi spacers can exhibit cis and trans conformations according to the different geometric needs of metal ions. For the three complexes, although their synthesis conditions are similar, the difference in coordination modes of the aromatic polycarboxylic acids and the versatile conformation of bix or bbi exert an important influence on the resulting supramolecular architectures; hence, each one of these compounds has a unique structural feature.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

 Syntheses. The mixture of metal salts and aromatic polycarboxylate with flexible imidazole-based spacers usually results in precipitation in traditional aqueous reactions, which makes it difficult to grow crystals of complexes. Therefore, complexes 1-3 were synthesized under hydrothermal methods. In addition, NaOH was introduced to deprotonate for aromatic polycarboxylate. Ligands SIP and 2,5-pydc can assume versatile coordination modes and are suitable H-bonding acceptors; meanwhile, both the flexible bix and bbi spacers can exhibit cis and trans conformations according to the different geometric needs of metal ions. For the three complexes, although their synthesis conditions are similar, the difference in coordination modes of the aromatic polycarboxylic acids and the versatile conformation of bix or bbi exert an important influence on the resulting supramolecular architectures; hence, each one of these compounds has a unique structural feature.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of 1. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that 1 adopts a 3-D supramolecular structure. As shown in Figure a, there exist two types of coordination environments around the cadmium ions in the crystal structure. Cd1, situated at an inversion center and in a distorted octahedral geometry, is coordinated by two sulfonate oxygen atoms from distinct SIP ligands occupying the apical positions, while the basal plane is completed by four different bbi nitrogen atoms; Cd2 is coordinated to two carboxylate oxygen atoms from inequivalent SIP ligands and three bbi nitrogen atoms in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal sphere. However, the Cd2−O4# [symmetry code # 1 + x, y, z] and Cd2−O7 distances are 2.753(3) and 2.713(3) Å, respectively, suggesting a non-negligible interaction with the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom, which can be described as a semichelating coordination mode. Hence, the Cd2 atom may be also regarded as in a distorted pentagonal bipyramid environment. Atom C26 shows positional disorder over two sites with equal occupancy. In 1, the Cd−O bond lengths range between 2.286(3) and 2.361(3) Å, while the Cd−N bond lengths vary from 2.251(3) to 2.312(4) Å, which are in the normal range.
elements.clean_text: Crystal Structure of 1. A single-crystal X-ray diffraction study reveals that 1 adopts a 3-D supramolecular structure. As shown in Figure a, there exist two types of coordination environments around the cadmium ions in the crystal structure. Cd1, situated at an inversion center and in a distorted octahedral geometry, is coordinated by two sulfonate oxygen atoms from distinct SIP ligands occupying the apical positions, while the  basal plane is completed by four different bbi nitrogen atoms; Cd2 is coordinated to two carboxylate oxygen atoms from inequivalent SIP ligands and three bbi nitrogen atoms in a distorted trigonal bipyramidal sphere. However, the Cd2-O4# [symmetry code # 1 + x, y, z] and Cd2-O7 distances are 2.753(3) and 2.713(3) Å, respectively, suggesting a non-negligible interaction with the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atom, which can be described as a semichelating coordination mode. Hence, the Cd2 atom may be also regarded as in a distorted pentagonal bipyramid environment. Atom C26 shows positional disorder over two sites with equal occupancy. In 1, the Cd-O bond lengths range between 2.286(3) and 2.361(3) Å, while the Cd-N bond lengths vary from 2.251(3) to 2.312(4) Å, which are in the normal range.

elements.content: Perspective views of (a) the coordination environments of the Cd ions, (b) the 1D ladder-like chain running along thea-axis based on SIP and Cd ions, (c) the 2D layer structure based on bbi and Cd ions, and (d) the 3D complicated framework in 1.
elements.clean_text: 1  Perspective views of (a) the coordination environments of the Cd ions, (b) the 1D ladder-like chain running along thea-axis based on SIP and Cd ions, (c) the 2D layer structure based on bbi and Cd ions, and (d) the 3D complicated framework in 1.

elements.content: It should be noted that there are three independent sets of bbi spacers, which establish physical bridges between Cd atoms. The set to which N1 belongs resides at a crystallographic inversion center and adopts a trans conformation. Both the set to which N5 belongs and the set to which N3 belongs exhibit cis configuration, with two pairs of imidazole groups twisted by 47° and 120°, respectively. It is worth mentioning that compound 1 is the first MOF in which bbi ligands can adopt cis geometry; in the case of the previously reported coordination framework based on bbi, all bbi spacers exhibit trans geometry.
elements.clean_text: It should be noted that there are three independent sets of bbi spacers, which establish physical bridges between Cd atoms. The set to which N1 belongs resides at a crystallographic inversion center and adopts a trans conformation. Both the set to which N5 belongs and the set to which N3 belongs exhibit cis configuration, with two pairs of imidazole groups twisted by 47° and 120°, respectively. It is worth mentioning that compound 1 is the first MOF in which bbi ligands can adopt cis geometry; in the case of the previously reported coordination framework based on bbi, all bbi spacers exhibit trans geometry.

elements.content: As displayed in Figure b, each SIP ligand is connected to three Cd2+ ions through its two monodentate carboxylate moieties, as well as one monodentate sulfonate group, and thereby acts as a μ3 bridging ligand, which is similar to the previously reported polymer [Cu1.5(SIP)(py)5](py)(H2O)6.76. The SIP ligand thus links cadmium ions to form a 1D ladder-like chain along the a-axis with Cd1···Cd2 separations of 8.646 Å and Cd2···Cd2 separations of 10.390 Å.
elements.clean_text: As displayed in Figure b, each SIP ligand is connected to three Cd2+ ions through its two monodentate carboxylate moieties, as well as one monodentate sulfonate group, and thereby acts as a μ3 bridging ligand, which is similar to the previously reported polymer [Cu1.5(SIP)(py)5](py)(H2O)6.76. The SIP ligand thus links cadmium ions to form a 1D ladder-like chain along the a-axis with Cd1⋅⋅⋅Cd2 separations of 8.646 Å and Cd2⋅⋅⋅Cd2 separations of 10.390 Å.

elements.content: The cis bidentate bbi molecules (to which N5 belongs) establish a physical bridge between Cd2 centers to form a 22-membered metallocycle with Cd2···Cd2 separations of 6.755 Å, which is further interlinked by cis-bbi (to which N3 belongs) and trans-bbi (to which N1 belongs) to generate a 2D layer structure (Figure c). The salient structural feature of compound 1 is that the cross-linkage of the 1D ladder-like chain and 2D layer structure leads to a complicated 3D network (Figure d). Moreover, the uncoordinated water molecule forms a strong hydrogen bond with the coordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms with separations of 2.868(5) and 2.765(5) Å, respectively.
elements.clean_text: The cis bidentate bbi molecules (to which N5 belongs) establish a physical bridge between Cd2 centers to form a 22-membered metallocycle with Cd2⋅⋅⋅Cd2 separations of 6.755 Å, which is further interlinked by cis-bbi (to which N3 belongs) and trans-bbi (to which N1 belongs) to generate a 2D layer structure (Figure c). The salient structural feature of compound 1 is that the cross-linkage of the 1D ladder-like chain and 2D layer structure leads to a complicated 3D network (Figure d).  Moreover, the uncoordinated water molecule forms a strong hydrogen bond with the coordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms with separations of 2.868(5) and 2.765(5) Å, respectively.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of 2. When another flexible imidazole-based spacer, bix, was introduced, a significantly different framework was formed in 2. As illustrated in Figure a, there are two cobalt(II) atoms, one SIP, and two bix ligands in the asymmetric unit. Apparently, the two cobalt atoms adopt distinct coordination environments. Co1 resides at a crystallographic inversion center and in a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, which is defined by two coordinated water molecules in the axial positions while the equatorial positions are furnished by four different bix nitrogen donors. The Co1−O1 length is 2.193(3) Å, whereas the Co1−N distances range from 2.110(3) to 2.135(3) Å. On the other hand, the Co2 metal center is in tetrahedral coordination linked by two carboxylate oxygen donors as well as two bix nitrogen donors. The Co2−O lengths vary from 1.911(3) to 1.940(3) Å, while the Co2−N distances range from 2.005(3) to 2.020(3) Å. Obviously, bond lengths in a tetrahedral geometry are shorter than those in octahedral geometries, which is consistent with those reported in the literature.
elements.clean_text: Crystal Structure of 2. When another flexible imidazole-based spacer, bix, was introduced, a significantly different framework was formed in 2. As illustrated in Figure a, there are two cobalt(II) atoms, one SIP, and two bix ligands in the asymmetric unit. Apparently, the two cobalt atoms adopt distinct coordination environments. Co1 resides at a crystallographic inversion center and in a distorted octahedral coordination sphere, which is defined by two coordinated water molecules in the axial positions while the equatorial positions are furnished by four different bix nitrogen donors. The Co1-O1 length is 2.193(3) Å, whereas the Co1-N distances range from 2.110(3) to 2.135(3) Å. On the other hand, the Co2 metal center is in tetrahedral coordination linked by two carboxylate oxygen donors as well as two bix nitrogen donors. The Co2-O lengths vary from 1.911(3) to 1.940(3) Å, while the Co2-N distances range from 2.005(3) to 2.020(3) Å. Obviously, bond lengths in a tetrahedral geometry are shorter than those in octahedral geometries, which is consistent with those reported in the literature.

elements.content: Perspective views of (a) the coordination environments of the Co ions, (b) a 1D infinite ladder-like chain arranged on thea-axis, and (c) the 3D hydrated framework in 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  Perspective views of (a) the coordination environments of the Co ions, (b) a 1D infinite ladder-like chain arranged on thea-axis, and (c) the 3D hydrated framework in 2.

elements.content: Each SIP ligand, serving as bisconnector through its two carboxylate moieties in monodentate mode whereas the protonated sulfonate group does not participate in the coordination, bridges a pair of Co2 centers with separation of 9.325 Å. The coordination mode of SIP ligands reported here is similar to that found in [{Cu(H2O)2(HSIP)}·2H2O·(PIP)1/2] n and is obviously distinct from that described above for 1. As for the bidentate bix ligands, they all adopt trans conformation in the structure. Figure b shows a 1D infinite ladder-like chain arranged in the a-axis, assembled from the bix ligand to which N3 belongs acting as rungs and the [CoSIP] unit serving as rails. The 1D chain is further stacked with another two bidentate bix (to which N1 and N7 individually belong), thus giving rise to the formation of a 3D hydrated framework (Figure c).
elements.clean_text: Each SIP ligand, serving as bisconnector through its two carboxylate moieties in monodentate mode whereas the protonated sulfonate group does not participate in the coordination, bridges a pair of Co2 centers with separation of 9.325 Å. The coordination mode of SIP ligands reported here is similar to that found in [{Cu(H2O)2(HSIP)}⋅2H2O⋅(PIP)1/2] n  and is obviously distinct from that described above for 1. As for the bidentate bix ligands, they all adopt trans conformation in the structure. Figure b shows a 1D infinite ladder-like chain arranged in the a-axis, assembled from the bix ligand to which N3 belongs acting as rungs and the [CoSIP] unit serving as rails. The 1D chain is further stacked with another two bidentate bix (to which N1 and N7 individually belong), thus giving rise to the formation of a 3D hydrated framework (Figure c).

elements.content: In fact, the uncoordinated water molecules are trapped in the pores, which constitute 1.9% of the unit cell volume. The lattice water molecule (O9) is involved in O−H···O hydrogen bonds falling into the range from 2.669(3) to 2.923(4) Å. Two kinds of strong hydrogen bonds are observed in the arrangement of 2:  (a) hydrogen bonds between coordinated water molecules and lattice water or sulfonate oxygen atoms; (b) hydrogen bonds between free water molecules and uncoordinated carboxylate or sulfonate oxygen atoms.
elements.clean_text: In fact, the uncoordinated water molecules are trapped in the pores, which constitute 1.9% of the unit cell volume. The lattice water molecule (O9) is involved in O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds falling into the range from 2.669(3) to 2.923(4) Å. Two kinds of strong hydrogen bonds are observed in the arrangement of 2: (a) hydrogen bonds between coordinated water molecules and lattice water or sulfonate oxygen atoms; (b) hydrogen bonds between free water molecules and uncoordinated carboxylate or sulfonate oxygen atoms.

elements.content: Crystal Structure of 3. The introduction of 2,5-pydc results in the formation of a corrugated 2D layer in 3. As illustrated in Figure a, the fundamental building unit of 3 is composed of a Cd center, one 2,5-pydc ligand, one and a half bix ligands, and one lattice water, in which each Cd center lies in a distorted octahedral coordination sphere completed by one nitrogen donor and one oxygen donor from a 2,5-pydc ligand, one carboxylate oxygen from another 2,5-pydc ligand, and three different bix nitrogen atoms. The Cd−O bond distances are all in the range between 2.248(3) and 2.361(3) Å, while the Cd−N bond lengths vary from 2.275(3) to 2.353(3) Å.
elements.clean_text: Crystal Structure of 3. The introduction of 2,5-pydc results in the formation of a corrugated 2D layer in 3. As illustrated in Figure a, the fundamental building unit of 3 is composed of a Cd center, one 2,5-pydc ligand, one and a half bix ligands, and one lattice water, in which each Cd center lies in a distorted octahedral coordination sphere completed by one nitrogen donor and one oxygen donor from a 2,5-pydc ligand, one carboxylate oxygen from another 2,5-pydc ligand, and three different bix nitrogen atoms. The Cd-O bond distances are all in the range  between 2.248(3) and 2.361(3) Å, while the Cd-N bond lengths vary from 2.275(3) to 2.353(3) Å.

elements.content: Perspective views of (a) the coordination environment of the Cd ion, (b) the 1D ribbon structure, and (c) the infinite corrugated 2D framework in3.
elements.clean_text: 3  Perspective views of (a) the coordination environment of the Cd ion, (b) the 1D ribbon structure, and (c) the infinite corrugated 2D framework in3.

elements.content: The 2,5-pydc ligand, acting as a bisconnector by monodentate carboxylate and pyridyl N moieties, links cadmium ions to form a 1D zigzag chain running along the b-axis with Cd···Cd distance of 8.906 Å.
elements.clean_text: The 2,5-pydc ligand, acting as a bisconnector by monodentate carboxylate and pyridyl N moieties, links cadmium ions to form a 1D zigzag chain running along the b-axis with Cd⋅⋅⋅Cd distance of 8.906 Å.

elements.content: For the cis-bix ligand (to which N2 belongs), imidazole planes are twisted by ca. 44°; for the trans-bix spacer (to which N6 belongs), located at a crystallographic inversion center, terminal imidazole groups have their planes steeply tilted by 85° with respect to the average plane of the phenyl ring. The cis-bix ligand also links cadmium centers to form a 1D chain, which is cross-linked with the 1D chain built from the 2,5-pydc moieties to generate a 1D ribbon structure (Figure b). The 1D ribbon is further interconnected by trans-bix to afford an infinite corrugated 2D framework (Figure c). Additionally, the 2D structure is cross-linked via medium hydrogen-bond interactions between lattice water molecules and the carboxylic acid moieties, thus bringing on a 3D framework.
elements.clean_text: For the cis-bix ligand (to which N2 belongs), imidazole planes are twisted by ca. 44°; for the trans-bix spacer (to which N6 belongs), located at a crystallographic inversion center, terminal imidazole groups have their planes steeply tilted by 85° with respect to the average plane of the phenyl ring. The cis-bix ligand also links cadmium centers to form a 1D chain, which is cross-linked with the 1D chain built from the 2,5-pydc moieties to generate a 1D ribbon structure (Figure b). The 1D ribbon is further interconnected by trans-bix to afford an infinite corrugated 2D framework (Figure c). Additionally, the 2D structure is cross-linked via medium hydrogen-bond interactions between lattice water molecules and the carboxylic acid moieties, thus bringing on a 3D framework.

elements.content: Some O···O hydrogen-bonding interactions were observed in the crystal structures of complexes 1−3; some important hydrogen bond data are listed in Table . These strong O···O hydrogen bonds play an important role in contributing to the stability of the 2D or 3D architecture.

Thermal Properties. Complexes 1, 2, and 3 are stable at ambient conditions, and thermogravimetric experiments were performed to explore their thermal stabilities. For 1, the weight loss of 2.68% from 40 to 250 °C (calcd 2.95%) corresponds to the loss of three free water molecules per formula. For 2, the first weight loss occurs in the range 95 to 140 °C, which is attributed to the departure of both the lattice and coordinated water molecules (obsd 4.19%, calcd 4.26%), followed by a plateau region ranging from 140 to 290 °C, and consecutive decompositions suggest the total destruction of the framework. For 3, the first weight loss of 2.54% below 175 °C is assigned to the liberation of free water molecules, which is in agreement with the calculated value (2.75%).
elements.clean_text: Thermal Properties. Complexes 1, 2, and 3 are stable at ambient conditions, and thermogravimetric experiments were performed to explore their thermal stabilities. For 1, the weight loss of 2.68% from 40 to 250 °C (calcd 2.95%) corresponds to  the loss of three free water molecules per formula. For 2, the first weight loss occurs in the range 95 to 140 °C, which is attributed to the departure of both the lattice and coordinated water molecules (obsd 4.19%, calcd 4.26%), followed by a plateau region ranging from 140 to 290 °C, and consecutive decompositions suggest the total destruction of the framework. For 3, the first weight loss of 2.54% below 175 °C is assigned to the liberation of free water molecules, which is in agreement with the calculated value (2.75%).

elements.content: Luminescent Properties. The emission spectra of complexes 1 and 3 in the solid state at room temperature were investigated, as depicted in Figure . Upon excitation at ca. 325 nm, complex 1 exhibits blue fluorescent emission bands at ca. 427 nm; for 3, emission bands at ca. 434, 488, 512, and 538 nm were observed. These emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature since Cd2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to their d10 configuration, which can probably be assigned to the intraligand (π−π*) fluorescent emission because similar emissions are observed at 355 nm for the free SIP, as well as 431, 455, 514, and 532 nm for the free 2,5-pydc ligand. The enhancement of the emissions for 1 and 3 compared with those of the free ligands may be ascribed to the increase in the ligand conformational rigidity due to their coordination to Cd(II) ions resulting in a decrease in the nonradiative decay of intraligand excited states. Those complexes may be used as a potential material for blue-light-emitting diode devices and may be candidates for thermally stable and solvent-resistant blue fluorescent material.
elements.clean_text: Luminescent Properties. The emission spectra of complexes 1 and 3 in the solid state at room temperature were investigated, as depicted in Figure . Upon excitation at ca. 325 nm, complex 1 exhibits blue fluorescent emission bands at ca. 427 nm; for 3, emission bands at ca. 434, 488, 512, and 538 nm were observed. These emissions are neither metal-to-ligand charge transfer (MLCT) nor ligand-to-metal charge transfer (LMCT) in nature since Cd2+ ions are difficult to oxidize or to reduce due to their d10 configuration, which can probably be assigned to the intraligand (π-π*) fluorescent emission because similar emissions are observed at 355 nm for the free SIP, as well as 431, 455, 514, and 532 nm for the free 2,5-pydc ligand. The enhancement of the emissions for 1 and 3 compared with those of the free ligands may be ascribed to the increase in the ligand conformational rigidity due to their coordination to Cd(II) ions resulting in a decrease in the nonradiative decay of intraligand excited states. Those complexes may be used as a potential material for blue-light-emitting diode devices and may be candidates for thermally stable and solvent-resistant blue fluorescent material.

elements.content: Solid-state emission spectra of polymers1 and 3 at room temperature.
elements.clean_text: 4  Solid-state emission spectra of polymers1 and 3 at room temperature.

elements.content: In summary, we have successfully isolated three new coordination polymers resulting from aromatic polycarboxylate acid and divalent transition metals in the presence of flexible imidazole-based spacers. All complexes have been characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR spectra, thermal analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. Complex 1 exhibits a complicated 3D network, which contains an infinite 1D ladder-like chain and 2D layer structure. Complex 2 possesses a 3D hydrated framework, while complex 3 adopts a corrugated 2D sheet. The difference in coordination modes of the aromatic polycarboxylic acids and the versatile conformation of bix or bbi exert an important influence on the resulting frameworks. Meanwhile, some intramolecular and intermolecular weak hydrogen-bonding interactions also play important roles in the formation of complexes. Moreover, the complexes 1 and 3 display strong blue emissions at room temperature; therefore, they appear to be good candidates for novel hybrid inorganic−organic photoactive materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In summary, we have successfully isolated three new coordination polymers resulting from aromatic polycarboxylate acid and divalent transition metals in the presence of flexible imidazole-based spacers. All complexes have been characterized by elemental analysis, FT-IR spectra, thermal analysis, and single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies. Complex 1 exhibits a complicated 3D network, which contains an infinite 1D ladder-like chain and 2D layer structure. Complex 2 possesses a 3D hydrated framework, while complex 3 adopts a corrugated 2D sheet. The difference in coordination modes of the aromatic polycarboxylic acids and the versatile conformation of bix or bbi exert an important influence on the resulting frameworks. Meanwhile, some intramolecular and intermolecular weak hydrogen-bonding interactions also play important roles in the formation of complexes. Moreover, the complexes 1 and 3 display strong blue emissions at room temperature; therefore, they appear to be good candidates for novel hybrid inorganic-organic photoactive materials.

cln_elements.content:
Synthesis of [Cd 3 (SIP) 2 (bbi) 5 ·3H 2 O] n (1). A mixture of CdCl2·2H2O (0.0568 g, 0.25 mmol), SIP (0.0672 g, 0.25 mmol), bbi (0.0241 g, 0.125 mmol), NaOH (0.0304 g, 0.75 mmol), and H2O (3.0 mL) was placed in a Parr Teflon-lined stainless steel vessel (25 cm3), and then the vessel was sealed and heated at 120 °C for 3 days. After the mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals of 1 were obtained (yield 22% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C66H82Cd3N20O17S2:  C 43.35, H 4.52, N 15.32%. Found:  C 43.28, H 4.55, N 15.30%. IR (cm-1, KBr):  3429 s, 3116s, 1682 m, 1611 s, 1562 s, 1519 s, 1467 m, 1435 m, 1354 s, 1293 m, 1232 s, 1220 s, 1182 s, 1102 s, 1089 s, 1043 s, 997 m, 932 s, 867 m, 831 m, 791 m, 777 s, 741 m, 723 s, 682 m, 663 s, 623 s, 581 m, 512 w, 445 m, 410 w.

Synthesis of [Co 3 (SIP) 2 (bix) 4 (2H 2 O)·2H 2 O] n (2). A mixture of Co(NO3)2·6H2O (0.0730 g, 0.25 mmol), SIP (0.0665 g, 0.25 mmol), bix (0.0612 g, 0.25 mmol), NaOH (0.0204 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (3.0 mL) was heated in an analogous procedure to that for 1. After the reactant mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, purple crystals of 2 were obtained (yield 39% based on Co). Anal. Calcd for C72H70Co3N16O18S2:  C 51.22, H 4.18, N 13.27%. Found:  C 51.25, H 4.25, N 13.32%. IR (cm-1, KBr):  3382 m, 3140w, 1644 m, 1618 s, 1570 m, 1520 m, 1448 w, 1432 m, 1389 m, 1339 s, 1284 w, 1237 m, 1215 s, 1200 s, 1190 s, 1095 s, 1039 s, 1025 w, 997 w, 953 w, 940 w, 919w, 858 m, 834 m, 776 m, 755 m, 720 s, 661 s, 633 s, 585 m, 554 m, 519 w, 476 w.

Synthesis of [Cd(2,5-pydc) 2 (bix) 1.5 ·H 2 O] n (3). A mixture of CdCl2·2H2O (0.0570 g, 0.25 mmol), 2,5-pydc (0.0422 g, 0.25 mmol), bix (0.0615 g, 0.25 mmol), NaOH (0.0212 g, 0.5 mmol), and H2O (3.0 mL) was heated at 140 °C for 3 days in an analogous to procedure to that for 1. After the reacant mixture was slowly cooled to room temperature, colorless crystals of 3 were obtained (yield 55% based on Cd). Anal. Calcd for C28H26CdN7O5:  C 51.50, H 4.01, N 15.02%. Found:  C 51.53, H 4.06, N 15.04%. IR (cm-1, KBr):  3419 s, 3112 m, 1626 s, 1520 w, 1479 w, 1446 w, 1393 s, 1358 s, 1304 w, 1285 m, 1272 w, 1235 m, 1175 w, 1147 w, 1109 m, 1085 m, 1036 m, 934 m, 892 w, 831 s, 765 s, 742 w, 719 w, 691 m, 657 m, 622 w, 536 m, 519 m, 412 w.
